conclusion: Real charge is +q at A(0, 0, h) in vacuum, and field-evaluation point P(h, h, –h) is inside the conductor.
In electrostatic equilibrium, E = 0 everywhere for z ≤ 0.
E(induced charges at P) + E(real charge at P) = 0, therefore E(induced)(P) = –E(real)(P).
Induced charges must produce an equal-magnitude, oppositely directed field to the real charge at P.
Vector from the source (0, 0, h) to P is r⃗ = (h, h, –2h).
Magnitude of the Coulomb field generated by +q at distance R is E_real = k q / (6h²).
|E_induced| = |E_real| = k q / (6h²) because the two fields cancel inside the conductor.
Direction of induced field is opposite to the field of the real charge.
Magnitude of the electric field produced by the induced charges at the point (h, h, –h) is E = k q / (6 h²).
